values.description:
If an exception is raised during file opening/creation, be sure to release the lock (if any) before raising the exception. 

Otherwise the lock is held until timeout, which means when you're writing code and make a mistake causing an exception, upon re-running your code it can hang for up to 45 seconds, so this fixes that.
values.title: Ensure h5_lock releases the lock in the case where the file cannot be opened.

summary.raw:

Otherwise the lock is held until timeout, which means when you're writing code and make a mistake causing an exception, upon re-running your code it can hang for up to 45 seconds, so this fixes that.
summary.html:
If an exception is raised during file opening/creation, be sure to release the lock (if any) before raising the exception.

Otherwise the lock is held until timeout, which means when you're writing code and make a mistake causing an exception, upon re-running your code it can hang for up to 45 seconds, so this fixes that.

values.description:
Change to setup_logging so that it attempts to use the program name to determine log location instead of the `__main__` module. This is because sometimes the `__main__` module is actually `zprocess.process_class_wrapper`, for subprocesses started using the zprocess.Process class. To prevent their logs ending up in the zprocess directory, we can use the name of the program to determine the location of that program's `__main__.py` module instead. This code falls back to the existing behaviour of using the `__main__` module for the filepath in the case of there being no importable module with the same name as the log.

This is particularly important on linux if you are not using
anaconda then zprocess may be installed somewhere without write permissions,
so the log file is not just misplaced but throws a permissions error.

The code here includes a hack to try the lowercase version of the program name, which is just for BLACS because the log name is 'BLACS' but the module name is 'blacs'.
values.title: setup_logging use program name instead of __main__ location for log file location

To prevent their logs ending up in the zprocess directory, we can use the name of the program to determine the location of that program's __main__.py module instead. values.description:
It turned out to be quite tricky to get a QLabel to elide its text in a way that was
compatible with it being rich text. Now we could just give up on having labels with
bold text in them, but that have been the easy way out.

This pull request adds a widget that, rather than being a QLabel with
elided text, wraps an existing QLabel, putting it in a QScrollArea so as
to only show part of the QLabel. An additional label displaying ellipsis "..."
is shown next to the QScrollArea to indicate that some of the text is not
being shown. This only really works well for single lines of text. The tooltip shows the full text.

The module also has a function for modifying an existing QLabel that already lives in a layout.
That way this can be applied to QLabels that from .ui files. This is done by reparenting the QLabel to the QScrollArea, and then inserting the result back into the layout at the position where the label was.

Minor version bump since new functionality introduced, so programs using this feature can
rely on check_version() to ensure they have the feautre. (version number with 'prerelease' suffix,
to be removed when tagged as a new version in mercurial. check_version works fine with this)

Here's a test: ![elide_label.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/KEMMje/images/3498332852-elide_label.png)
values.title: Qt widget for eliding QLabel with rich text

values.description:
Fix bug in which ToolPalette would not shrink to its minimum size when placed in a layout, not shrinking smaller than a certain size. For larger vertical sizes (larger than QScrollArea's default minimumSizeHint of about 75 pixels it seems) it was not noticeable, but once there was only one or two rows of widgets they would be allocated too much space. In BLACS the DigitalOutput buttons don't don't grow like the tool buttons do in the below screenshots, so in BLACS instead this resulted in a large amount of space between the rows of buttons. 

The problem was because size in a layout is set be the sizeHint and minimumSizeHint properties, rather than the minimumSize property (confusingly).

So I implemented ToolPalette.sizeHint() and ToolPalette.minimumSizeHint(),
which communicate to the parent layout what the size should be in a layout.

Also fixed minor error in height calculation, which did not distinguish between
margins and spacing and so was off by a few pixels (likely not noticeable before I changed the spacing and margins to be different from each other in an earlier pull request).

So total height is now calculated as (for number of rows n):

 `n * widget_height + (n - 1) * spacing + top_margin + bottom_margin`

Before:

![toolpalette_before.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/KEMMje/images/1129253231-toolpalette_before.png)

After:

![tool_palette_after.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/KEMMje/images/4041797923-tool_palette_after.png)
values.title: ToolPalette vertical size bugfix

summary.html:
Fix bug in which ToolPalette would not shrink to its minimum size when placed in a layout, not shrinking smaller than a certain size. For larger vertical sizes (larger than QScrollArea's default minimumSizeHint of about 75 pixels it seems) it was not noticeable, but once there was only one or two rows of widgets they would be allocated too much space. In BLACS the DigitalOutput buttons don't don't grow like the tool buttons do in the below screenshots, so in BLACS instead this resulted in a large amount of space between the rows of buttons.

The problem was because size in a layout is set be the sizeHint and minimumSizeHint properties, rather than the minimumSize property (confusingly).

So I implemented ToolPalette.sizeHint() and ToolPalette.minimumSizeHint(), which communicate to the parent layout what the size should be in a layout.

Also fixed minor error in height calculation, which did not distinguish between margins and spacing and so was off by a few pixels (likely not noticeable before I changed the spacing and margins to be different from each other in an earlier pull request).

So total height is now calculated as (for number of rows n):

n * widget_height + (n - 1) * spacing + top_margin + bottom_margin

values.description:
Not sure if this is an issue on Windows, but for me when I scroll past SpinBoxes they steal focus, I stop scrolling, and the mousewheel starts manipulating their values instead. This is not what one wants in a lab control system.

- Subclassed QDoubleSpinBox for use with analog output widgets so that they
don't steal focus when you scroll over them. You can still scroll on them to
change their value if they've been focused by a mouse click or tab, but
scrolling over them will not focus them, and scrolling elsewhere whilst they
are focused will cause them to lose focus, so you can scroll with confidence.

Also converted the file to one type of line ending (not intentionally, again), so for ease of reading here is the diff with whitespace changes ignored:


```
#!diff

--- a/qtwidgets/analogoutput.py	Mon Jun 19 00:58:18 2017 +0000
+++ b/qtwidgets/analogoutput.py	Tue Jun 20 02:33:15 2017 -0400
@@ -15,28 +15,50 @@
 
 if 'PySide' in sys.modules.copy():
     from PySide.QtCore import *
     from PySide.QtGui import *
 else:
     from PyQt4.QtCore import *
     from PyQt4.QtGui import *
 
+
+class NoStealFocusDoubleSpinBox(QDoubleSpinBox):
+    """A QDoubleSpinBox that doesn't steal focus as you scroll over it with a
+    mouse wheel."""
+    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
+        QDoubleSpinBox.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
+        self.setFocusPolicy(Qt.StrongFocus)
+
+    def focusInEvent(self, event):
+        self.setFocusPolicy(Qt.WheelFocus)
+        return QDoubleSpinBox.focusInEvent(self, event)
+
+    def focusOutEvent(self, event):
+        self.setFocusPolicy(Qt.StrongFocus)
+        return QDoubleSpinBox.focusOutEvent(self, event)
+
+    def wheelEvent(self, event):
+        if self.hasFocus():
+            return QDoubleSpinBox.wheelEvent(self, event)
+        else:
+            event.ignore()
+
 class AnalogOutput(QWidget):
     def __init__(self, hardware_name, connection_name='-', display_name=None, horizontal_alignment=False, parent=None):
         QWidget.__init__(self,parent)
         
         self._connection_name = connection_name
         self._hardware_name = hardware_name
         
         label_text = (self._hardware_name + '\n' + self._connection_name) if display_name is None else display_name
         self._label = QLabel(label_text)
         self._label.setAlignment(Qt.AlignCenter)
         self._label.setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy.Fixed,QSizePolicy.Minimum)
-        self._spin_widget = QDoubleSpinBox()
+        self._spin_widget = NoStealFocusDoubleSpinBox()
         self._spin_widget.setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy.MinimumExpanding,QSizePolicy.Minimum)
         self._spin_widget.setKeyboardTracking(False)
         self._combobox = QComboBox()
         self._combobox.setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy.Minimum,QSizePolicy.Minimum)
         self._combobox.currentIndexChanged.connect(self._on_combobox_change)
         
         self._value_changed_function = None
         

```
values.title: Make analog output widgets not steal focus on scrolling

summary.html:
Not sure if this is an issue on Windows, but for me when I scroll past SpinBoxes they steal focus, I stop scrolling, and the mousewheel starts manipulating their values instead. This is not what one wants in a lab control system.

  • Subclassed QDoubleSpinBox for use with analog output widgets so that they don't steal focus when you scroll over them. You can still scroll on them to change their value if they've been focused by a mouse click or tab, but scrolling over them will not focus them, and scrolling elsewhere whilst they are focused will cause them to lose focus, so you can scroll with confidence.

Also converted the file to one type of line ending (not intentionally, again), so for ease of reading here is the diff with whitespace changes ignored:

--- a/qtwidgets/analogoutput.py Mon Jun 19 00:58:18 2017 +0000
+++ b/qtwidgets/analogoutput.py Tue Jun 20 02:33:15 2017 -0400
@@ -15,28 +15,50 @@

 if 'PySide' in sys.modules.copy():
     from PySide.QtCore import *
     from PySide.QtGui import *
 else:
     from PyQt4.QtCore import *
     from PyQt4.QtGui import *

+
+class NoStealFocusDoubleSpinBox(QDoubleSpinBox):
+    """A QDoubleSpinBox that doesn't steal focus as you scroll over it with a
+    mouse wheel."""
+    def __init__(self, *args, **kwargs):
+        QDoubleSpinBox.__init__(self, *args, **kwargs)
+        self.setFocusPolicy(Qt.StrongFocus)
+
+    def focusInEvent(self, event):
+        self.setFocusPolicy(Qt.WheelFocus)
+        return QDoubleSpinBox.focusInEvent(self, event)
+
+    def focusOutEvent(self, event):
+        self.setFocusPolicy(Qt.StrongFocus)
+        return QDoubleSpinBox.focusOutEvent(self, event)
+
+    def wheelEvent(self, event):
+        if self.hasFocus():
+            return QDoubleSpinBox.wheelEvent(self, event)
+        else:
+            event.ignore()
+
 class AnalogOutput(QWidget):
     def __init__(self, hardware_name, connection_name='-', display_name=None, horizontal_alignment=False, parent=None):
         QWidget.__init__(self,parent)

         self._connection_name = connection_name
         self._hardware_name = hardware_name

         label_text = (self._hardware_name + '\n' + self._connection_name) if display_name is None else display_name
         self._label = QLabel(label_text)
         self._label.setAlignment(Qt.AlignCenter)
         self._label.setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy.Fixed,QSizePolicy.Minimum)
-        self._spin_widget = QDoubleSpinBox()
+        self._spin_widget = NoStealFocusDoubleSpinBox()
         self._spin_widget.setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy.MinimumExpanding,QSizePolicy.Minimum)
         self._spin_widget.setKeyboardTracking(False)
         self._combobox = QComboBox()
         self._combobox.setSizePolicy(QSizePolicy.Minimum,QSizePolicy.Minimum)
         self._combobox.currentIndexChanged.connect(self._on_combobox_change)

         self._value_changed_function = None

values.description:
* Add testing_utils module, which provides a TestCase class appropriate for
    running tests on a GUI program running in the main thread, with the tests
    running in a separate thread, within the framework of the standard
    library's unittest module. The module also contains a few utilities for
    mocking objects with the `mock` module.

* Added PY2 constant to __init__.py, bumped minor version  so other code can rely on the it and the 
    testing_utils submodule to exist.
    Skipped version 2.3 since it was never tagged as a release even though
    the version string was there and programs were depending on it.

* Made check_version a bit smarter. Now, in the case of a failed import, it attempts to nonetheless 
    read the version string from the failed import, if it can. If the version string would cause a version 
    error, it prints that in addition to the exception raised during import. This can help diagnose when 
    imports are failing - if they are failing due to a version mismatch, then a traceback mentioning
    the version mismatch is useful.
values.title: Utilities for test suites, PY2 constant, minor version bump, smarter check_version()

summary.raw:
* Add testing_utils module, which provides a TestCase class appropriate for
    running tests on a GUI program running in the main thread, with the tests
    running in a separate thread, within the framework of the standard
    library's unittest module. The module also contains a few utilities for
    mocking objects with the `mock` module.

* Added PY2 constant to __init__.py, bumped minor version  so other code can rely on the it and the 
    testing_utils submodule to exist.
    Skipped version 2.3 since it was never tagged as a release even though
    the version string was there and programs were depending on it.

* Made check_version a bit smarter. Now, in the case of a failed import, it attempts to nonetheless 
    read the version string from the failed import, if it can. If the version string would cause a version 
    error, it prints that in addition to the exception raised during import. This can help diagnose when 
    imports are failing - if they are failing due to a version mismatch, then a traceback mentioning
    the version mismatch is useful.
summary.html:
• Add testing_utils module, which provides a TestCase class appropriate for running tests on a GUI program running in the main thread, with the tests running in a separate thread, within the framework of the standard library's unittest module. The module also contains a few utilities for mocking objects with the mock module.

  • Added PY2 constant to init.py, bumped minor version so other code can rely on the it and the testing_utils submodule to exist. Skipped version 2.3 since it was never tagged as a release even though the version string was there and programs were depending on it.

  • Made check_version a bit smarter. Now, in the case of a failed import, it attempts to nonetheless read the version string from the failed import, if it can. If the version string would cause a version error, it prints that in addition to the exception raised during import. This can help diagnose when imports are failing - if they are failing due to a version mismatch, then a traceback mentioning the version mismatch is useful.

values.description:
This pull request along with it's sister pull requests introduces qtutil's new abstraction layer for Qt. This abstraction layer is supposed to act like PyQt5. A few adjustments needed to be made so things don't break.

This pull request should also bring PyQt5 compatibility but this should be experimental at first so reviewing should not include this as a criterium for approval. (This has been discussed [here](https://pstarkey.github.io/bitbucket-archive/#!/pull-requests/1/pyqt5/diff#comment-41775691))

To test this one needs to also pull from my qtutils repo [here](https://bitbucket.org/PhyNerd/qtutils/).

values.description:
* Reimplemented dragdroptab.

    Lost: ~~mouse icon changing during drag~~, ~~animation when moving tabs
    within a tabbar~~.

    Gained: Doesn't crash or lose tabs, tabs are always in a tabbar (just possibly one floating in free    
    space) reducing the need for workarounds when a tab wants to manipulate its state (title, icon
    etc) while a drag is in progress.

    The lost functionality ~~can plausible be re-added without compromising
    on the lack of crashing. I just haven't looked into it much yet~~ has been restored.

This pull request may fix issue #13 (I can't test, I don't have a mac, but I expect it will since I'm now storing which tab is being dragged based on the position of the mouse click rather than which tab was active at the time of the click), [likely fixes BLACS issue #17](#!/labscript_suite/blacs/issues/17/tab-becomes-unselected-when-moving), and does fix the issue I've seen in testing pull request #20.

This reimplementation is based on abandoning Qt's drag and drop functionality, and implementing it instead with just mouseEvents. It turns out to be much easier, since there was unending subtleties with Qt's drag events. The main one being that if during an event you called functions that modified the GUI, this could actually cause *new events to be processed, including the very event handler you were already in*. So you would have to write all the code to be re-entrant even though it's single threaded. I attempted to serialise the events by catching them and putting them in a queue to process in order rather than re-entrantly but that caused Qt to fire seemingly nonsensical events like two leave events in a row for the same widget and other nonsense that entirely defeats the purpose of the drag events if you can't trust anything about them.

This change is compatible with the Qt5 pull request (it just has a try/except for the imports for now so that it works regardless, can be changed to just use qtutils.qt after that branch is merged), though the merge might have to be done locally to discard the other file as otherwise it looks like a merge conflict.

summary.html:
• Reimplemented dragdroptab.

    Lost: mouse icon changing during drag, animation when moving tabs within a tabbar.

    Gained: Doesn't crash or lose tabs, tabs are always in a tabbar (just possibly one floating in free
    space) reducing the need for workarounds when a tab wants to manipulate its state (title, icon etc) while a drag is in progress.

    The lost functionality can plausible be re-added without compromising on the lack of crashing. I just haven't looked into it much yet has been restored.

This pull request may fix issue #13 (I can't test, I don't have a mac, but I expect it will since I'm now storing which tab is being dragged based on the position of the mouse click rather than which tab was active at the time of the click), likely fixes BLACS issue #17, and does fix the issue I've seen in testing pull request #20.

This reimplementation is based on abandoning Qt's drag and drop functionality, and implementing it instead with just mouseEvents. It turns out to be much easier, since there was unending subtleties with Qt's drag events. The main one being that if during an event you called functions that modified the GUI, this could actually cause new events to be processed, including the very event handler you were already in. So you would have to write all the code to be re-entrant even though it's single threaded. I attempted to serialise the events by catching them and putting them in a queue to process in order rather than re-entrantly but that caused Qt to fire seemingly nonsensical events like two leave events in a row for the same widget and other nonsense that entirely defeats the purpose of the drag events if you can't trust anything about them.

This change is compatible with the Qt5 pull request (it just has a try/except for the imports for now so that it works regardless, can be changed to just use qtutils.qt after that branch is merged), though the merge might have to be done locally to discard the other file as otherwise it looks like a merge conflict.

values.description:
Under macOS the hostname is not fixed and changes depending on the network environment, this creates lots of new config files for mobile machines. This pull request replaces the hostname with the LocalHostName (which is constant und macOS) as a identifier for config files.

It's tested under macOS only but for other platforms there should be no changes.

values.description:
This file contains a command line camera server for Pointgrey/FLIR usb3 cameras. It optionally utilizes the new acquistion_ROI property of the camera class. To start the server, type "python PyCapture2_camera_server.py <cameraNameFromBlacs>" in a command line running in the labscript_utils directory.

This is a fairly simple server that is working well in my lab and gives some idea of how to move away from Labview. It would be nice to have a GUI and serve multiple cameras in a single server, but I'm leaving that for future extensions. Note that the server requires both the FlyCapture2 SDK and the PyCapture2 python wrapper to function.

DSB

P.S.
After the initial commit, I discovered that setting the black level (brightness) to zero causes strange stripes on "dark" images of absorption imaging sequence. I hard coded in a black level of ~1%. It would probably be better to set black level on a per camera basis in the future.

values.description:
This pull request aims at bringing Python 2/3 compatibility to the labscript suite.

The changes are mostly printfunctions adjustments, string/unicode compatibility, future imports and explicit int division.

I also added a file containing a function to convert lists of dtypes to dicts of dtypes for numpy. This is because numpy doesn't like non native strings in dtype lists but in dicts they are fine.

* **future** imports added to unitconversions and Python 3 changes
* Added future imports to all files
* Python3 changes
* Python 3 string/exception handeling in properties.py
* some unicode adjustments for properties.py and a function to convert a list of dtypes to a dict of dtypes to fix some problems with numpy

values.description:
* The way `exec()` was used in unit conversions was not Python 3 compatible and not really possible  to make Python 3 compatible in a clean way, so I've changed it to not use `exec()`.

* Made the metric prefix conversion factors be stored as floats instead of strings, removing the use of `eval()` in operations involving them.

* renamed `UnitConversion.units` → `UnitConversion._magnitude_list` since it is internal and to make it slightly less confusable with all the other things called units.

* Simplified the sorting logic

I grepped labscript_suite to check that nothing was depending on the class variable `UnitConversion.units` since I changed it's name, and that nothing was depending on the fact that the metric prefix conversion factors were previously strings.

I've tested basic functionality on Python 2 and 3:


```
#!python

import labscript_utils.unitconversions.example as example
import random
magnitudes = ['p', 'n', 'u', 'm', 'k', 'M', 'G', 'T']
random.shuffle(magnitudes)
e = example.example3({'magnitudes': magnitudes})
print(e.W_to_base(0.7))
print(e.mW_to_base(0.7))
print(e.mW_from_base(0.000325))

print(e._magnitudes.keys())
print(e.derived_units)
```

python2:
```
0.325
0.000325
0.7
['G', 'M', 'k', 'm', 'n', 'p', 'u', 'T']
[u'pW', u'nW', u'uW', u'mW', u'W', u'kW', u'MW', u'GW', u'TW']
```
python3:
```
0.32499999999999996
0.000325
0.7
dict_keys(['m', 'p', 'T', 'k', 'n', 'M', 'G', 'u'])
['pW', 'nW', 'uW', 'mW', 'W', 'kW', 'MW', 'GW', 'TW']
```
Note that the magnitudes list is in an arbitrary order (its a dict now), but that doesn't matter since its a private variable and the sorting logic that produces `derived_units` doesn't require it to be sorted anymore.
values.title: Unit conversions Python3 bugfix and cleanup

values.description:
This is a Python import hook that records the filepath of any modules imported (if they have a filepath), and if later a module with the same filepath is imported under a different name, raises an exception. This is to prevent the 'double import' problem, where two copies of the same module can exist in memory at the same time. I consider this a bug in Python, and it's a terrible one, but this import hook can make sure you find out quickly if you've made this mistake, helping prevent bugs like [BLACS issue #36](#!/labscript_suite/blacs/issues/36/front-panel-settings-not-loaded-correctly)

With this patch, BLACS (version prior to last night's backout of import changes) crashes on startup with:


```
#!python

RuntimeError: Double import! The same file has been imported under two
different names, resulting in two copies of the module. This is almost
certainly a mistake. If you are running a script from within a package and
want to import another submodule of that package, import it by its full path:
'import module.submodule' instead of just 'import submodule.'

Path imported: /home/bilbo/labscript_suite/blacs/connections.py

Traceback (first time imported, as connections):
------------
  File "__main__.py", line 126, in <module>
    from connections import ConnectionTable
------------

Traceback (second time imported, as blacs.connections):
------------
  File "__main__.py", line 138, in <module>
    from blacs.experiment_queue import QueueManager, QueueTreeview
  File "/home/bilbo/labscript_suite/blacs/experiment_queue.py", line 35, in <module>
    from connections import ConnectionTable
------------
```

With the absolute imports backed out, it doesn't crash because 'experiment_queue', being imported with `import experiment_queue` from `__main__`, doesn't think it's part of a package, and so it is importing 'connections' also as a non-package module. But if `experiment_queue` is imported as a submodule as `blacs.experiment_queue`, then when it does `import connections` in Python 2, that's also a submodule.

With this patch, BLACS is failing to load plugins because it is mixing import types with regard to plugins (without this patch, it is loading plugin modules twice).

So this shouldn't be merged immediately - it should be pulled for testing so we can stamp out the mixed imports (we should turn them all into fully qualified absolute imports: `from blacs.plugins import blah blah`), and once we're done we should merge this in so that it alerts us to any future screwups.
values.title: Double import denier

With the absolute imports backed out, it doesn't crash because 'experiment_queue', being imported with `import experiment_queue` from `__main__`, doesn't think it's part of a package, and so it is importing 'connections' also as a non-package module. But if `experiment_queue` is imported as a submodule as `blacs.experiment_queue`, then when it does `import connections` in Python 2, that's also a submodule.

With this patch, BLACS is failing to load plugins because it is mixing import types with regard to plugins (without this patch, it is loading plugin modules twice).

So this shouldn't be merged immediately - it should be pulled for testing so we can stamp out the mixed imports (we should turn them all into fully qualified absolute imports: `from blacs.plugins import blah blah`), and once we're done we should merge this in so that it alerts us to any future screwups.
summary.html:
This is a Python import hook that records the filepath of any modules imported (if they have a filepath), and if later a module with the same filepath is imported under a different name, raises an exception. This is to prevent the 'double import' problem, where two copies of the same module can exist in memory at the same time. I consider this a bug in Python, and it's a terrible one, but this import hook can make sure you find out quickly if you've made this mistake, helping prevent bugs like BLACS issue #36

With this patch, BLACS (version prior to last night's backout of import changes) crashes on startup with:

RuntimeError: Double import! The same file has been imported under two
different names, resulting in two copies of the module. This is almost
certainly a mistake. If you are running a script from within a package and
want to import another submodule of that package, import it by its full path:
'import module.submodule' instead of just 'import submodule.'

Path imported: /home/bilbo/labscript_suite/blacs/connections.py

Traceback (first time imported, as connections):
------------
  File "__main__.py", line 126, in <module>
    from connections import ConnectionTable
------------

Traceback (second time imported, as blacs.connections):
------------
  File "__main__.py", line 138, in <module>
    from blacs.experiment_queue import QueueManager, QueueTreeview
  File "/home/bilbo/labscript_suite/blacs/experiment_queue.py", line 35, in <module>
    from connections import ConnectionTable
------------

With the absolute imports backed out, it doesn't crash because 'experiment_queue', being imported with import experiment_queue from __main__, doesn't think it's part of a package, and so it is importing 'connections' also as a non-package module. But if experiment_queue is imported as a submodule as blacs.experiment_queue, then when it does import connections in Python 2, that's also a submodule.

With this patch, BLACS is failing to load plugins because it is mixing import types with regard to plugins (without this patch, it is loading plugin modules twice).

So this shouldn't be merged immediately - it should be pulled for testing so we can stamp out the mixed imports (we should turn them all into fully qualified absolute imports: from blacs.plugins import blah blah), and once we're done we should merge this in so that it alerts us to any future screwups.

values.description:
This modifies `Connectiontable.get_attached_devices` to only return local devices and Remote Workers that are directly connected to it. Devices of type `RemoteWorkerBroker` and `RemoteWorkerBroker`  are also not as they are no real devices and the device import in BLACS fails otherwise.

Additionally `Connection.BLACS_connection`  now splits off all remote connections and stores them in `Connection.remote_connections`.
values.title: Prepare Connectiontable for Remote Workers

values.description:
Give `memprof.start()` a keyword argument to allow specifying a filename.

This is important since BLACS no longer `os.chdir()`s to its directory (which other apps should change to stop doing as well), so the current working directory could be anything if BLACS is started with `python -m blacs`. So BLACS needs to be able to specify a filepath to memprof.

Also do not activate memprof by default - it is the importer's responsibility
to call start() (the BLACS plugin already does this)

Also refactored memprof into a class rather than using global variables.
values.title: Allow specifying an output file to memprof

Also do not activate memprof by default - it is the importer's responsibility
to call start() (the BLACS plugin already does this)

Also refactored memprof into a class rather than using global variables.

values.description:
This change should make the constructor of ConnectionTable constructor return a empty connection table if anything goes wrong during creation.

Any exceptions will be raised in a thread.

This will allow BLACS to start even when things go wrong.

values.description:
NameErrors in properties.py that would break if vlenstrings are used
in connection tables (which we may switch to at some point), and connections.py
not converting numpy strings correctly (in Python 3, np.str_ passes isinstance for unicode, not bytes).

Also, conversion to string in properties.py did not convert numpy strings to Python strings. Pretty inconsequential (only old labscript files have these I think), but for consistency Python unicode strings should be returned for everything.
values.title: Bugfixes for string conversion

Also, conversion to string in properties.py did not convert numpy strings to Python strings. Pretty inconsequential (only old labscript files have these I think), but for consistency Python unicode strings should be returned for everything.
summary.html:
NameErrors in properties.py that would break if vlenstrings are used in connection tables (which we may switch to at some point), and connections.py not converting numpy strings correctly (in Python 3, np.str_ passes isinstance for unicode, not bytes).

Also, conversion to string in properties.py did not convert numpy strings to Python strings. Pretty inconsequential (only old labscript files have these I think), but for consistency Python unicode strings should be returned for everything.

values.description:
Do not replace stdout and stderr with os.devnull if sys.stdout is not a tty, only if it is None (Windows pythonw.exe Py3) or has a negative file descriptor (Windows pythonw.exe Py2). This allows for the case where sys.stdout is a zprocess output redirector, in which case we still want output.

Patch bump to 2.7.1 so BLACS can depend on this change for worker terminals.
values.title: Logging fix

values.description:
Added the 'exceptions\_in\_thread' keyword to ConnectionTable. If it is True exceptions in the constructor will be raised in a thread. Otherwise exceptions will be raised regularly.

This in combination with pull request [https://bitbucket.org/labscript\_suite/blacs/pull-requests/45/made-use-of-connectiontables/diff](#!/labscript_suite/blacs/pull-requests/45/made-use-of-connectiontables/diff) will fix a bug in BLACS where BLACS won’t start if a queued experiment file doesn’t exists.
values.title: Added the 'exceptions_in_thread' keyword to ConnectionTable.

values.description:
Do not check if string is QVariant if QVariant not present in qt library.
PySide2 does not have a QVariant type (and the check is not needed if using PySide2)
so this fixes an incompatibility with PySide2.
values.title: Avoid QVariant NameError
